overall_assessment.summary: The research questions show good theoretical grounding but the current model structure is insufficient to fully address the complexity of the phenomena. RQ1 has moderate alignment, RQ2 has poor alignment, and RQ3 has very poor alignment. Significant model expansion and additional theoretical frameworks are needed for PhD-level contribution.

theory_fit.assessment: Communities of Practice provides strong theoretical foundation for understanding peripheral-to-core transitions. SECI model complements by explaining knowledge conversion mechanisms. Together they cover learning and knowledge transfer aspects well.
gaps: Missing theories on motivation and retention
No theoretical framework for skill acquisition progression
Limited coverage of social and organizational barriers

model_fit.assessment: Basic structure captures progression through states but lacks granularity. Missing critical variables like motivation, social integration, project complexity, and individual capability differences.
gaps: No representation of motivation or engagement

critical_issues.issue: Model lacks mechanisms for individual differences in capability and motivation
No representation of social and organizational barriers to progression
Oversimplified linear progression ignores complex career paths

theories_to_add.why: Explains motivational factors affecting progression and retention
Captures social integration and relationship dynamics in OSS communities

theory_fit.assessment: Current theories provide limited direct support for intervention design. Communities of Practice suggests mentorship and participation structures, but lacks systematic intervention frameworks.
gaps: No theory of change or intervention design

model_fit.assessment: Model cannot test interventions as it lacks policy levers and intervention mechanisms. Current structure is descriptive rather than prescriptive.
gaps: No way to measure intervention effectiveness

critical_issues.issue: Model cannot simulate interventions or policy changes
No theoretical basis for intervention design
Missing metrics to evaluate intervention success

theories_to_add.why: Provides framework for designing learning interventions and organizational change
Offers systematic approaches to intervention design and evaluation

theory_fit.assessment: Current theories have almost no connection to system failure or vulnerability prevention. SECI model touches on knowledge preservation but doesn't address security or system reliability.

model_fit.assessment: Model completely lacks variables related to code quality, security vulnerabilities, or system failure. Cannot address RQ3 with current structure.

critical_issues.issue: Complete misalignment between model and research question
No theoretical foundation for security/vulnerability analysis
Model cannot represent software quality or failure mechanisms

theories_to_add.why: Provides framework for measuring and modeling software quality attributes

theories_to_add.theory: Normal Accident Theory (Perrow) or High Reliability Organization theory
theories_to_add.why: Explains system failure mechanisms in complex systems
Captures accumulation of quality issues over time

actionable_steps.step: Refine RQ3 to align with current theoretical foundation or significantly expand theoretical scope
actionable_steps.rationale: Current RQ3 requires completely different theories and model structure than RQ1-2

actionable_steps.step: Expand model with motivational and social integration variables for RQ1
actionable_steps.rationale: Essential for capturing dynamics of peripheral-to-core transition

actionable_steps.step: Add intervention policy levers and evaluation metrics to model
actionable_steps.rationale: Required to address RQ2 about interventions

actionable_steps.step: Conduct literature review on OSS quality and security dynamics
actionable_steps.rationale: Build theoretical foundation for RQ3 or reformulate the question

actionable_steps.step: Validate model structure with empirical data from OSS projects
actionable_steps.rationale: Ensure model represents real-world progression patterns
